creating_layers_in_a_photo::preview_card: Sometimes it can be effective to reverse the subject and context layers.
The most basic application of this idea for photojournalism is to create two distinct layers: a subject layer and a second layer that provides context to the story.
To create depth in a photo, compose in distinct layers: foreground and background. Sometimes a third layer, a middle ground, is used.
The second layer, often the background layer, can be composed to help the viewer better understand the subject's environment and the story.
creating_layers_in_a_photo::title: Creating Layers in a Photo
creating_layers_in_a_photo::clip_card_0:: Place the subject or character in a distinct layer from the rest of the image.
creating_layers_in_a_photo::text_card_1:: Practice shooting photos with distinct layers, one with a clear subject and another that provides context.
creating_layers_in_a_photo::preview_card: Complex photographs may have three layers, each illustrating a different element of the story.
creating_layers_in_a_photo::text_card_0:: Compose your photos with layers to create depth. Layers help the two dimensional space of a photograph better represent the three-dimensional world.
creating_layers_in_a_photo::preview_card: The main subject of your photo can be a person or an object. It should be placed on one distinct layer of the frame.
